title: (x) The Beatles "Revolver" - (similar to) Grot 9 {Richard Hards}
content:
Hi,

I need to know which type is used for the “Revolver” writing on the front-cover of the Revolver LP from The Beatles. I am no pro so I am completely lost with this.

You can see the cover here: [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:Revolver.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040620/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:Revolver.jpg "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:Revolver.jpg")

Can somebody plz help?!

ThX

vink

 [‹ (x) The American Republic - ITC Golden Cockerel {Mike F}](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040620/http:/typophile.com/node/19053 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Phamous 69 magazine - Fortuna Dot (Futura Dot) {Mike F} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040620/http:/typophile.com/node/19023 "Go to next forum topic")
author: vink

comments.content: Yeah I’d say Helvetica, it’s easily recognized by the captial Rs where the leg of the R on the right hand side hooks out just at the bottom.

Whoops, not [Helvetica](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040620/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=LH.108076.0.27&attributes.sampleSize=48&sampleText=REVOLVER&sampleSize=48). The type in question has noticeable stroke contrast (see the V and O), of which Helv has very little. There was also not a lot of squooshing going on in the pre-digital days.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040620im_/http:/typophile.com/files/revolver.png)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040620im_/http:/typophile.com/files/NeueHelvetica77CondensedBold.png)
  
 [Neue Helvetica 77 Condensed Bold](http://web.archive.org/)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040620im_/http:/typophile.com/files/HelveticaInserat.png)
  
 [Helvetica Inserat](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040620/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=LH.120906.0.24&attributes.sampleSize=48&sampleText=REVOLVER&sampleSize=48)

We’re looking at a gothic that’s possibly not available digitally, but here are some options:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040620im_/http:/typophile.com/files/BureauGrotesqueThreeFive.png)
  
 [Bureau Grotesque Three Five](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040620/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=FB.613.0.4&attributes.sampleSize=48&sampleText=REVOLVER&sampleSize=48)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040620im_/http:/typophile.com/files/BureauGrotesqueThreeSeven.png)
  
 [Bureau Grotesque Three Seven](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040620/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=FB.6603.0.4&attributes.sampleSize=48&sampleText=REVOLVER&sampleSize=48) (closest I can find)

Similar: [Gothic No. 13](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040620/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=LH.107991.0.1&attributes.sampleSize=48&sampleText=REVOLVER&sampleSize=48), [Gothic No. 4](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040620/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=C.612.0.4&attributes.sampleSize=48&sampleText=REVOLVER&sampleSize=48)
Yeah the O had me wondering if it was Helvetica. I did not spot the V though, nice catch.

I would have thought, putting it into historical/geographical context, that it was more likely to [Stephenson Blake](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040620/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Stephenson%252BBlake)’s [Grot 9](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040620/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/urw/grotesque-no-9/)

Richard

Would have been Typositor set originally - and maybe a bit “starved”. There were loads of cuts of “Grot 9” floating about back then - plenty of typesetters cut their own versions from specimen books. Grot 9 is bang on for period.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071118040620im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Revolver.jpg)
